It sounds like you're experiencing some discomfort and pain in your shoulder and arm due to tendonitis. Tendonitis is an inflammation of the tendons, which are the tissues that connect muscles to bones. It can be caused by overuse or repetitive motion, and can be quite painful.
 It's possible that you may need to take some time off from using your arm and shoulder to allow the tendon to heal. In the meantime, you can try some gentle stretching and resting to help alleviate the pain.

It's also important to make sure you're getting enough sleep and taking care of yourself overall. Lack of sleep can exacerbate pain and make it more difficult to recover from injuries.

Last night in class, we discussed the assigned reading, "Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World," by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter focuses on "implacement" and the second, "displacement." In the first chapter, Casey highlights that our contemporary world and culture revolve around time as the dominant situating force, emphasizing that we are running out of time, we have saved time, and we are just in time. He argues that shifting the center of culture to place can foster a more grounded community. So far, this book is the first reading that has captivated me with its thought-provoking ideas.

Ahimsa, or non-violent resistance, is a concept that has been central to Indian philosophy and politics for centuries, particularly in the teachings of Mahatma Gandhi. In his book, "My Experiments with Truth," Gandhi reflects on the importance of non-violence and its relevance to modern society. He writes, "As my conception of ahimsa went on maturing, I became more vigilant about my thought and speech. The head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales, Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, has spoken out against the ongoing conflict in Iraq, calling it a "terrible waste of money" and urging that funds be redirected towards reducing poverty and improving living standards around the world.
Speaking on BBC Radio 4's "Thought for the Day" slot, the Cardinal criticized the fact that "billions" of pounds have been spent on the conflict in Iraq, rather than being used to address the "dire poverty, malnutrition, and disease" that affects millions of people globally. He emphasized that 2005 should be a year of campaigning to "make history" and "make poverty history."

The Cardinal's comments come as a joint statement by the Archbishop of Canterbury and the Catholic Church in England and Wales was issued, calling for an end to the conflict in Iraq and a shift in priorities towards addressing global poverty and inequality. The statement noted that the war in Iraq has resulted in the deaths of thousands of innocent civilians and has caused widespread destruction and suffering, while the needs of the world's poorest people remain unmet.

In his Christmas message, the Cardinal urged people to reflect on the true meaning of Christmas and the importance of promoting peace, justice, and compassion in the world.

Halloween screenwriter and producer Debra Hill, best known for her work on the 1978 horror classic Halloween, has died in Los Angeles at the age of 54. Hill, who had been suffering from cancer, co-wrote the film, which starred Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, it grossed over $60 million worldwide, a record for an independent film at the time. Hill also worked with Carpenter on the films Escape from New York and The Fog. Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant and worked her way up through the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before collaborating with Carpenter. She was regarded by many as a pioneering woman in the film industry, taking on jobs in the 1970s that were typically held by men.

"Yukos Fights for Survival in US Court as Russian Authorities Seek $27B Tax Payment"

Yukos, a US-registered oil and gas company, is fighting for its survival in a US court as Russian authorities seek to collect a $27 billion tax bill. The company, which is in the process of being broken up by Russian authorities, is using international business law to try to halt the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. The unit was sold for $9.4 billion to state-owned oil firm Rosneft, but only after the state auction had been disrupted. Yukos lawyers now say the auction violated US bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to go after any company that buys its assets, using all and every legal means.

Voters flock to blog awards site voting is under way for the annual bloggies, which recognize the best web blogs - online spaces where people publish their thoughts - of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but traffic to the official site was so heavy that the website was temporarily closed due to too many visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a huge year, with a top US dictionary naming "blog" word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs and says that more than 12,000 are added daily. A blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to US research think-tank Pew Internet and American Life, but less than 40% of the total are updated at least once every two months.

Chinese dam builder 'defies Beijing' as Three Gorges Corp. continues work on sister Xiluodu dam despite government order to stop construction. The Xiluodu dam is one of 30 large-scale construction projects ordered to halt due to lack of proper environmental checks, but the company has ignored the order and may instead pay a fine. The firm has also disregarded shutdown orders for two other projects - the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Project Electrical Power Supply Plant - despite being ordered to do so by the state environmental protection agency (SEPA).

Manchester City 0-2 Manchester United reduced Chelsea's Premier League lead to nine points after a scrappy victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney met Gary Neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which went in via a deflection off Richard Dunne, to put United ahead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate Dunne hooked a volley over David James' head and into his own net. Steve McManaman wasted City's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes, United had looked unlikely to earn the win they needed to keep any chance of catching Chelsea in the title race. Their approach play was more labored than patient and they managed to fashion just one chance - a Paul Scholes header over the bar in the first half.

Wales 'must learn health lessons' new health minister says. Dr Brian Gibbons, on his first full day in the job after Jane Hutt was sacked, admitted 'big challenges' but insisted 'essentials' were in place. But both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats said Dr Gibbons needed to change policy. Meanwhile, Ms Hutt defended her record, saying waiting times and lists were 'only 10% of the health agenda.' Dr Gibbons, who was a GP in Blaengwynfi, in the upper Afan valley, before becoming AM for Aberavon, said NHS staff wanted a period of consolidation after 'tremendous change and reform.' One of the biggest problems that faced Ms Hutt during her five-and-a-half years as the Assembly's first Health Minister was the length of waiting lists in Wales.

Ferguson lauds United's gritty win at Aston Villa. Manchester United manager Alex Ferguson praised his players' determination and grit in their 1-0 win at Aston Villa, hailing it as their toughest away game of the season. 'That was a fantastic game of football, end-to-end with plenty of good passing,' he said. 'We showed great character and guts and we weren't going to let them beat us. I look at that fixture and see that Arsenal and Chelsea still have to come and Villa may have some players back when they do.' Ferguson also singled out senior stars Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who came off the bench for the injured John O'Shea, saying, 'Roy came on and brought a bit of composure to the midfield which we needed and no other player could provide.'

George Michael will be the subject of a documentary at this year's Berlin Film Festival. The film, titled "George Michael: Freedom and Love," will provide a candid look at the life of the chart-topping singer and songwriter. It will premiere in the Panorama section of the festival, which runs from February 10-20, and will feature Michael discussing both his career and his personal life, from his days in Wham! to more recent events.
Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on February 16. Director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens will also be in attendance. The 93-minute film will see Michael discussing his early days in Wham!, as well as his later career, including his legal battles with record label Sony and his stance against the Iraq war and American politics.

Green Day's "Boulevard of Broken Dreams" is currently at number two on Billboard's Hot 100 chart, and tops its digital chart. Download sales are set to be incorporated into the UK singles chart later this year. Digital sales in the US are already used to compile Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. They will now be tallied with sales of physical singles and airplay information to make up its new Hot 100 chart. Its second new chart, the Pop 100, combines airplay, digital, and physical sales, but confines its airplay information to US radio stations that play chart music.

Anti-spam laws have bitten the self-proclaimed "spam king" hard. Scott Richter, the man behind OptinRealBig.com and billions of junk messages, is seeking bankruptcy protection. The company is fighting several legal battles, most notably against Microsoft, which is seeking millions of dollars in damages. The company claims that filing for Chapter 11 will help it resolve its legal problems while still conducting business. OptinRealBig was listed as the third biggest spammer in the world by junk mail watchdog SpamHaus, and was sued in December 2003 for sending billions of spam messages that violated anti-spam laws. The lawsuit was brought by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, who alleged that Richter and his accomplices sent spam messages through 514 compromised net addresses in 35 countries.

Ireland surged past Scotland in their Six Nations match at Murrayfield, securing an impressive victory over the hosts. Hugo Southwell's try gave Scotland an early 8-0 lead, but scores from Locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put the visitors in command by half-time. A third try from Wing Denis Hickie and a third penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed the victory for Ireland. After two hard-earned away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's side can now look forward to welcoming England to Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Scotland will aim to give their coach Matt Williams a first Six Nations victory when Italy come to Edinburgh, but they again struggled to turn pressure into points.

England are looking to secure their third autumn international victory in the Tri-Nations tournament as they take on Australia in the final game of the series at Elland Road. The English team is determined to avenge their 51-15 thrashing by the Wallabies in June, and a win over the Wallabies would be a massive achievement, especially given their recent successes against Canada and South Africa. A victory for Great Britain would also end 34 years of consecutive losses against Australia, and give them a chance to end their long losing streak against the Wallabies.

Iraq Invites Bids for Phone License, Seeks to Boost Nationwide Coverage

Iraq has invited bids from local, Arab, and foreign companies to develop and operate a fixed phone network, with the aim of significantly increasing the country's telephone service penetration rate. The Ministry of Communications has announced that it is seeking to boost the country's telecommunication sector and create a highly visible and changeable telecommunications sector.

The bidding process will be published on the ministry's website on February 9, and a road-show for investors in Amman, Jordan, is also planned. The successful bidder will work in partnership with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC) to install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax, and internet services.

According to the ministry, the goal is to increase Iraq's telephone service penetration rate from the current 4.5% to around 25% within the next 10 years. The ministry believes that this will help to develop a highly visible and changeable telecommunications sector, and will play a significant role in the country's economic and social development.

More women are taking charge of protecting their home computers from cyber threats, according to a two-year study on net security. The number of women purchasing software to protect their personal computers from viruses, spam, and spyware rose by 11.2% annually between 2002 and 2004. The study, conducted by a leading internet security firm, suggests that 40% of those buying home security software are retired individuals. This is a significant increase from previous years, with retired women accounting for 53% of the purchases in the last three years, an average annual growth rate of 13.2%. This trend reflects both the changing demographics of internet users and growing awareness of the potential threats posed by high-speed broadband connections.

Levy takes Whitbread novel prize, favorite to win overall award
Andrea Levy has won the Whitbread novel of the year award for her book Small Island. She is now the favorite to win the overall prize after beating Booker winner Alan Hollinghurst's The Line of Beauty. Geraldine McCaughrean has picked up the children's fiction award for the third time for Not the End of the World. All category winners will compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which comes with a Â£25,000 prize. A panel of judges, including Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris, will meet on January 25 to decide the overall winner, with the announcement being made that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has placed Levy's novel as the 6/4 favorite to win.

Yukos, the company that seeks court action on sale, will return to a US court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the little-known firm that bought the main asset. Yukos' US lawyers will attempt to have Baikal's assets frozen after the Russian government ignored a US court order last week blocking the sale. Yukos' lawyers claim that Baikal has strong links with Surgutneft, Russia's fourth-largest oil producer, and that the sale of the Yuganskneftegas production unit was part of a scheme to avoid paying the company's debts.

Scotland's Justice Minister, Cathy Jamieson, has issued a warning to bigoted soccer fans that she intends to target them "where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Roxy Music to Headline Isle of Wight Festival

The article discusses the proposed plans of the Conservative party to give local communities the power to elect their own police commissioners. The plan would see the creation of a new office, the police commissioner, who would be elected by the local community to oversee the police force in their area. The Conservatives argue that this would give communities more control over their local police force and allow them to hold the police to account.

Paris, France - Saturday's epic match between Wales and France has left fans and pundits alike in awe. The Welsh team's stunning victory has raised hopes of a Welsh Grand Slam, the first since 1978, and has sparked a renewed sense of national pride in Wales.

New drink-drive limit 'could save 65 lives a year', report says

Cutting the drink-drive limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg could save 65 lives a year, according to a report published by the parliamentary advisory council for transport safety. The findings are being presented as MPs prepare to vote on the government's road safety bill, which includes changes to speeding fines but not the drink-drive limit. The research, conducted by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, also suggests that a lower limit would lead to 230 fewer serious injuries on the UK's roads compared to 2003. The previous estimate, contained in a 1998 Department of Transport document, suggested that a lower limit could save 50 lives a year.

This paper presents a millimeter-scale CMOS 64$\times$64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1$\times$1 $\mu m^2$ diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design provides a large detection area of 512$\times$512 $\mu m^2$. Instead of sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures the pulse width, i.e., the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline. This obviates the need for using power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC is fabricated in TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process and consumes the average static power of 0.535 mW under 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The functionality of the whole system is successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam setting.

Online reviews provide customers with valuable product evaluations, but they can also be manipulated by professional spammers using increasingly sophisticated spamming strategies. These strategies are difficult to detect, as they evolve rapidly, vary among spammers, and remain largely unknown. Most existing detectors prioritize detection accuracy, but this approach is not optimal for maintaining the trustworthiness of product evaluations. To address these challenges, we formulate a game-theoretic approach that pits spammers and detectors against each other, with each side seeking to maximize their respective goals. The Nash equilibria of this game lead to detectors that are robust against a wide range of spamming strategies.

We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high fidelity (uh-fidelity) population transfer on a 3-level quantum system in lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we use the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method to derive a family of solutions leading to an exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the L-R invariant. Among this family, we identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to control simultaneously the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We define a measure of the robustness of an uh-fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation on the pulse areas at which the infidelity rises above $10^{-4}$. The robustness of our shaped pulses is found superior to that of Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas."

In this paper, we investigate the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function of Gaussian mixture models with an arbitrary number of components. Due to nonconvexity, there exist multiple local minima that are not globally optimal, even when the mixture is well-separated. We show that all local minima share the same form of structure, which involves fitting multiple Gaussians to a single true component and fitting a single Gaussian to multiple true components. Our results hold for the setting where the true mixture components satisfy a certain separation condition, and are valid even when the number of components is over- or under-specified. For Gaussian mixtures with three components, we obtain sharper results in terms of the scaling with the separation between the components.

We consider the connection between two constructions of the mirror partner for the Calabi-Yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as a quotient by some suitable subgroup $g$ of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface $x_m$ in the weighted projective space, cut out by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial $w_m$. The first, Berglund-H\"ubsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction, uses another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface $x_{m^t}$ inside it by some dual group $g^t$. In the second, Batyrev construction, the mirror partner is constructed as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We present a novel mixed variable symplectic (MVS) integrator for planetary systems that resolves close encounters with unprecedented accuracy. Our method combines a high-order MVS scheme with a time regularization technique, enabling us to maintain the stability properties of symplectic integrators while reducing the effective step size during close encounters. This allows for larger time steps far from close encounters, making the algorithm more efficient. We demonstrate the long-term behavior of our algorithm on systems of six super-Earths experiencing strong scattering over 50 kyr, showing that it can accurately resolve almost exact collisions while using the same time step as in weakly perturbed problems like the solar system. We compare our method to hybrid approaches like Mercury and show that, for the same computational cost, it offers significantly better energy conservation.

Entanglement is a crucial resource for quantum information processing. A widely used tool for detecting entanglement is entanglement witness, which measures the witness operator and is guaranteed to be positive for separable states and can be negative for entangled states. However, as the number of parties involved in the system increases, it becomes increasingly difficult to create an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states. For $n$-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states, the most robust witness scheme requires $n+1$ local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/2$ white noise. In contrast, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states requires only two local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/3$ white noise.

Within general relativity, the unique stationary solution of an isolated black hole is the Kerr spacetime, which has a peculiar multipolar structure depending only on its mass and spin. We develop a general method to extract the multipole moments of arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply it to a large family of horizonless microstate geometries. The latter can break the axial and equatorial symmetry of the Kerr metric and have a much richer multipolar structure, which provides a portal to constrain fuzzball models phenomenologically. We find numerical evidence that all multipole moments are typically larger (in absolute value) than those of a Kerr black hole with the same mass and spin. Current measurements of the quadrupole moment of black-hole candidates could place only mild constraints on fuzzballs, while future gravitational-wave detections of extreme mass-ratio inspirals with the space mission LISA will improve these bounds by orders of magnitude."

In addition, we develop an emulator to obtain fast predictions of the baryonic power suppression, allowing us to perform a likelihood inference analysis for a standard Î›CDM cosmology with both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

The authors of the paper propose an open-source neural network approach to classify audio segments into vocalizations produced by a child wearing a recording device, vocalizations produced by other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. To develop this model, they gathered a diverse corpus of child-centered recordings, totaling 260 hours of recordings and covering 10 languages. The goal of the project is to provide a tool for analyzing and understanding the quantity and quality of speech that children produce, as well as for early diagnosis and measuring the effects of remediation. The tails of diboson production at the LHC are sensitive to the interference between standard model and higher-dimensional operators, which parameterize the effects of heavy new physics. However, helicity selection rules for diboson scattering amplitudes impose an obstruction to naive interference contributions from dimension six operators, effectively cancelling the leading contribution to the total diboson rate correction. In this case, measuring the azimuthal decay angles "resurrects" the interference, recouping sensitivity to the non-interfering operators. We explore these signatures in detail and find that the EFT uncertainties associated with higher-dimensional operators are uniquely well-suppressed by the construction of an asymmetry variable that is generated only by these non-interfering operators, relegating the effects of higher-dimensional, interfering operators to the same status as statistical errors in this observable.

Understanding how strongly correlated two-dimensional (2D) systems can exhibit unconventional superconductivity with high critical temperatures is one of the major unsolved problems in condensed matter physics. Ultracold 2D fermi gases have emerged as clean and controllable model systems to study the interplay of strong correlations and reduced dimensionality, but direct evidence of superfluidity in these systems has been lacking. In this study, we demonstrate superfluidity in an ultracold 2D fermi gas by moving a periodic potential through the system and observing no dissipation below a critical velocity, v$_{\rm c}$. We measure v$_{\rm c}$ as a function of interaction strength and find a maximum in the crossover regime between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. Our measurement establishes ultracold fermi gases as a powerful tool for studying the influence of reduced dimensionality on strongly correlated superfluids.

Metal ion implantation into ceramics has been demonstrated to be an effective and controllable technique for tailoring the surface electrical conductivity of the ceramic piece, and this approach has been used in a number of applications. Importantly, it provides a method for grading the voltage drop across high voltage insulators, and thereby increasing the maximum operational voltage that can be applied across the insulator without surface flashover. However, a concern for the use of this method is the long-term stability of the implantation-induced conductivity, especially if the implanted metal species is readily oxidized.

Here, we report on our examination of the long-term behavior of the surface conductivity of titanium-implanted alumina. The results indicate that after an initial drop of as much as 40% in the first few weeks after implantation, the conductivity shows only a very slow decrease of about 10% over the following year.

We generalize the Furusaki-Tsukada formula, which got initially established to quantify usual (tunneling) Josephson current flows, to evaluate the transverse current components and demonstrate that their amplitudes are widely adjustable by means of the spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference across the junction. Continuous-time quantum walks have proven to be a valuable framework for the design of various quantum algorithms. The running time of these algorithms is often characterized by the quantum hitting time, the time required for the quantum walk to find a vertex of interest with high probability. In this article, we present improved upper bounds for the quantum hitting time that can be applied to several ctqw-based quantum algorithms. Specifically, we improve the hitting time upper bound for the glued-trees problem from $o(n^5)$ to $o(n^2\log n)$. Additionally, our methods also exponentially improve the dependence on precision of the continuous-time quantum walk-based algorithm to find a marked node on any ergodic, reversible Markov chain, as shown by Chakraborty et al.

Existing works on user cold-start recommendation either require additional user efforts, such as setting up an interview process, or make use of side information, like user demographics, locations, social relations, etc. However, users may not be willing to provide this information, and side information on cold-start users is usually not available.

While some gains have been achieved by learning individual parts of a receiver, a better approach is to jointly learn the whole receiver. Mutation-based fuzzing typically employs an initial set of non-crashing seed inputs (a corpus) from which to generate new inputs through mutation. A typical corpus may contain thousands of similar inputs, leading to wasted fuzzing effort through exhaustive mutation from all available seeds. To address this, fuzzers utilize distillation tools (e.g., afl-cmin) that select the smallest subset of seeds that trigger the same range of instrumentation data points as the full corpus. Common practice suggests that minimizing the number and cumulative size of the seeds leads to more efficient fuzzing, which we systematically explore. We present results from 34+ CPU-years of fuzzing with five distillation approaches to understand their impact in discovering bugs in real-world software."

In this paper, we investigate multi-agent discrete-event systems with partial observation. Electric network frequency (ENF) fluctuations constitute a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. A type of Gohrberg-Semencul factorization of the model covariance matrix is used due to the Toeplitz structure of the covariance matrix. Moreover, this approach uses, for the first time in the field of ENF, a temporal window, not necessarily the rectangular one, at the stage preceding spectral estimation. The proposed approach outperforms the state-of-the-art methods in ENF estimation, when a short time window of $1$ second is employed in power recordings. The Direpack package aims to introduce a suite of modern statistical dimension reduction techniques into the Python universe as a unified package. The included methods fall into three categories: projection pursuit-based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M-estimators for dimension reduction. As a corollary, regularized regression estimators based on these reduced dimension spaces are also provided, ranging from classical principal component regression to sparse partial least squares regression. The package additionally includes a collection of classical and robust preprocessing utilities, such as generalized spatial signs, as well as dedicated plotting tools and cross-validation utilities. Furthermore, Direpack has been designed to be consistent with the scikit-learn API, allowing the estimators to seamlessly integrate into statistical and/or machine learning pipelines within that framework.

In this paper, the authors propose a new method for conducting Bayesian inference in survey research that takes into account the random effects of survey sampling. They argue that traditional methods of Bayesian inference, which rely on numerical integration, can be biased due to the fact that the sampling design is often ignored in the estimation process. The authors propose a weight-exponentiated formulation of the Bayesian model that allows for unbiased estimation of hyperparameters, as well as consistent inference for the population distribution. The authors demonstrate the effectiveness of their approach through simulations and real-data examples, showing that it outperforms frequentist methods in terms of both unbiasedness and consistency with the population distribution. This work represents a significant contribution to the field of survey research, as it provides a new and improved approach to Bayesian inference that can help to address the limitations of traditional methods.
